questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with chronic burning pain, numbness, and tingling on the right side of her body not relieved with NSAIDs. The symptoms began 2 months after she suffered a stroke. On examination, she has hyperesthesia and allodynia on the right side. The clinician suspected it to be due to lacunar infarct. What could be the likely site of infarct causing her present symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Ventroposterolateral thalamus Explanation: Chronic burning pain not relieved by usual NSAIDs following a stroke is due to lacunar infarct of Ventroposterolateral Thalamus , known as Dejerine-Roussy syndrome (aka) Thalamic pain syndrome . Dejerine Roussy syndrome: Cause Lacunar infarct of penetrating branches of PCA (P1 segment) Clinical features Hemianesthesia affecting one half of body (initially) [Hemisensory loss] Later causing burning pain sensation (during recovery) O/E: Hyperaesthesia, allodynia may be present on the affected side Treatment Carbamazepine, Gabapentin, TCAs (Tricyclic antidepressants) Small vessel stroke: Cause Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis Risk factors Hypertension: Most common Diabetes Atrial fibrillation Smoking Hyperlipidemia Sites & manifestations Posterior limb of internal capsule (Option B) Pure motor hemiparesis Genu of internal capsule (Option C) Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness) Cortical pontocerebellar tract (Option D) I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis Ventroposterolateral thalamus (Option A) Dejerine-Roussy syndrome Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, 173, 3326, 3327, 3328, 3341

questions.question: An elderly patient presented with a history of slowing of movements, frequent falls and forgetfulness. MRI done is as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Bradykinesia and tremors Explanation: MRI shows Hummingbird sign - suggestive of Progressive supranuclear palsy [PSP] (a Parkinson-plus disorder). Tremors are not a feature of PSP . Progressive supranuclear palsy [PSP] Early onset postural instability - H/O frequent falls + Dementia Tremors - absent (Option B) Defective downward gaze (Option A) + extended posture of body Dystonia: Procerus sign (forehead) + Gunslinger’s gait (flexion at elbow & adduction at upper limb) (Option D) Poor response to levodopa (Option C) MRI: Hummingbird sign Lewy body dementia [LBD] Parkinsonian features + Visual hallucination + early Dementia Associated REM sleep disorder may be present Multiple systemic atrophy [MSA] MSA-A: Autonomic instability + (orthostatic hypotension) MSA-C: Cerebellar symptoms + ; MRI- Hot cross bun sign (Pons) Corticobasal syndrome [CBS] Dystonia + myoclonus + alien limb phenomena present alone with other parkinsonian features bun sign" data-author="Moreira, Ana Sofia & Castro, Miguel & Grande, Pablo & Gameiro, Ana & Bahia Soares, Carla & Costa, Yessica & Silva, Luís & Saraiva, José & Dinis, Mónica." data-hash="9232" data-license="NA" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Hot-Cross-Bun-Sign-Head-T2W-MRI-thou gh-the-pons-showing-a-hyperintense-pontine-cross_fig2_314914201" data-tags="April2025"

questions.question: Which of the following clinical signs of upper motor neuron lesion is described correctly ? response.Babinski’s sign - Lateral stroke of the sole resulting in flexion of all toes response. response

options.A: Gordon’s sign - A stroke beneath and in front of the lateral malleolus causing an extensor plantar
options.B: Gordon’s sign - A stroke beneath and in front of the lateral malleolus causing an extensor plantar
options.C: Oppenheim’s sign - Apply pressure along the medial aspect of tibia causing an extensor plantar
options.D: Chaddock’s sign - Squeeze the calf muscles to produce extensor plantar response.

questions.explanation: extensor plantar response Correct Answer: C) Oppenheim’s sign - Apply pressure along the medial aspect of tibia causing an extensor plantar response. Explanation : Oppenheim’s sign is elicited by applying pressure along the medial aspect of tibia to cause an extensor plantar response i.e. dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes. (Option C) Babinski’s sign is elicited by stroking the lateral aspect of the sole from the heel towards the little toe and then continuing up to the great toe. This results in an extensor plantar response as described above in a case of upper motor neuron lesion. Flexion of all toes indicates a normal person or the presence of a lower motor neuron lesion. (Option A ruled out) Gordon’s sign is elicited by squeezing the calf muscles to produce an extensor plantar response. (Option B ruled out) Chaddock’s sign is elicited by stimulating the dorsolateral aspect of the foot from the posterior portion of the skin just beneath the lateral malleolus anteriorly and along the external edge of the foot. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A 5 year old female child presented to the casualty with recurrent seizures and left sided hemiplegia. On physical examination, a reddish skin lesion was found since birth over the right side of her forehead involving the right eye, nose and cheek. On CT imaging of the brain, the following picture was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sturge Weber syndrome Explanation: The given clinical scenario of a 5 year old female child with complaints of recurrent seizures , left sided hemiplegia with a description of port-wine stain in the right ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve and a CT image showing the classical tram-track or rail-road sign suggests a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome . It is a sporadic disorder neurocutaneous syndrome characterised by a facial nevus or ‘port wine stain’ in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve along with an ipsilateral ‘ rail road pattern/tram-track ’ of intracranial parallel cortical calcification and glaucoma. questions.question: A 15 year old adolescent male patient came with his parents with complaints of neuropsychiatric symptoms such as tremors and an irritable mood. On physical examination, hepatomegaly and the following ophthalmological finding is seen. What is the probable diagnosis and gene involved in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Wilson’s disease and ATP7B gene Explanation: The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male with neuropsychiatric symptoms , hepatomegaly and ophthalmological finding of Kayser-Fleischer ring is suggestive of Wilson’s disease and the gene involved is ATP7B gene in chromosome 13 . (ATP 7A In menke kinky hair disease) Wilson’s disease Description Wilson's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to defective copper excretion and increased copper accumulation in organs such as the liver, brain, and eyes , resulting in hepatolenticular degeneration. Clinical features Hepatic : Jaundice, hepatomegaly, ascites; chronic liver disease may develop by age 40 . Neurological : Dysarthria, rigidity, tremors, uncoordinated handwriting. Psychiatric : Personality changes such as irritable mood, depression and anxiety. Ocular : Kayser-Fleischer rings (copper deposits in the Descemet’s membrane of cornea) and sunflower cataracts. Other : Delayed puberty, renal tubular dysfunction, skeletal issues (osteoporosis, rickets), hemolytic anemia. Investigations Biochemical : Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin , elevated hepatic transaminases, aminoaciduria, hemolytic anemia. Diagnostic Tests : Increased urinary copper excretion; liver biopsy for hepatic copper measurement (values >200 µ g/g dry weight is definitive of Wilson’s disease). Treatment Copper Chelation : D-penicillamine enhances urinary copper excretion. Alternatives include trientine hydrochloride. Zinc Therapy :

questions.question: A 30 year old male patient was brought to the casualty with a history of road traffic accident and sustained multiple injuries. On primary assessment, he was disoriented and complained of his worst and most painful headache he ever had. On CT brain imaging, the following image was seen. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Subarachnoid haemorrhage Explanation: The most probable diagnosis in this patient is subarachnoid haemorrhage as the patient had a traumatic brain injury with the patient describing his headache as the worst headache he ever had (thunderclap headache) and CT brain findings suggestive of hyperdensities in bilateral sylvian cisterns and the basal cistern . Subarachnoid haemorrhage Etiology Most common cause is head injury . Most common non-traumatic cause is due to saccular (berry) aneurysms , often at the circle of Willis - most commonly anterior communicating artery . Other causes include non-aneurysmal (perimesencephalic) haemorrhages, arteriovenous malformations and vertebral artery dissection. Increased risk in cases of polycystic kidney disease , and connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome ). Clinical

questions.question: A 75 year old male patient came to the OPD with complaints of recent onset stooping, broad based abnormal gait, short-term memory loss and urge incontinence. On radiological investigation, the following image is obtained. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Normal pressure hydrocephalus Explanation: The given clinical scenario of an elderly male patient with complaints of recent onset stooping, broad based abnormal gait ( gait apraxia/ gait instability ), short term memory loss ( dementia ) and urge incontinence and on radiological investigation the image shows bilateral lateral ventriculomegaly which is suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus. Normal pressure hydrocephalus It is also called Hakims–Adams syndrome which is seen usually in the elderly above 60 years of age with the classical triad of urinary incontinence, dementia and gait instability ( wet,wacky and wobbly ). Shuffling gait with preserved arm swing in NPH (Arm swing lost in Parkinsonism) Other key features include bilateral ventriculomegaly and usually a normal CSF (6-28 cm of H 2 O) opening pressure although can be increased in some cases. Treatment includes shunt procedures such as ventriculo-peritoneal shunting. Parkinson’s disease (Option A): Although there is presence of a stooping gait in this case it does not denote a classical festinant

questions.question: A 13 year old male patient presented with complaints of poor scholastic performance, history of recurrent seizures since infancy and the following incidental finding on his back. What does the incidental finding denote and probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Shagreen patch and Tuberous sclerosis Explanation: The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male patient with complaints of poor scholastic performance ( low IQ ), history of recurrent seizures since infancy and clinical image showing shagreen patch suggests a probable diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis (BOURNEVILLE DISEASE) Pathophysiology It is an autosomal dominant disorder. Genes involved are TSC1 in chromosome 9 producing hamartin protein and TSC2 is on chromosome 16 producing tuberin protein . Both these proteins play a role in cell growth and cell division. Mutations lead to aberrant activation of mTOR pathway signalling giving rise to various tumours. Clinical features Classical triad of seizures (epilepsy), low IQ, facial angiofibromas ( adenoma sebaceum )- EPILOIA Other skin manifestations include shagreen patches, hypomelanotic macules ( Ash leaf macules ), periungual fibromas ( Koenen tumours ) Associated with renal angiomyolipomas , cardiac rhabdomyomas (in children) Increased risk of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs) Treatment Anticonvulsants for seizures mTOR inhibitors (sirolimus or everolimus) for SEGAs and seizure reduction Adenoma sebaceum and Tuberous sclerosis (Option B): It is incorrect since the image shows a shagreen patch and not adenoma sebaceum. Neurofibroma and Neurofibromatosis (Options A) and Cafe-au-lait spots and Neurofibromatosis (Option D): Neurofibromas and cafe-au-lait spots are associated with neurofibromatosis . They are also associated with seizures but do not show shagreen patches.

questions.question: Which of the following is false on findings of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?

options.A: Periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG
options.C: Increased intensity in the basal ganglia
options.D: All prion diseases are characterized by spongiform changes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All prion diseases are characterized by spongiform changes (vacuolisation inside cells) Explanation: FFI (Fatal familial insomnia) a type of prion disease does not show this change All of the findings are true in case of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD.) It is a rare, fatal degenerative brain disorder caused by prion proteins. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) findings: Electroencephalography (EEG) Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) (Option A ruled out) These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages. MRI findings Increased intensity in the basal ganglia (Option C ruled out) Cortical ribboning (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: Based on the MRI finding (shown below) , Which of the following criteria and corresponding treatment used in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) McDonald’s criteria, IV Steroids Explanation: MRI shows Dawson’s fingers , characteristic finding in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) . Criteria used is McDonald’s criteria and IV Methylprednisolone (Steroid) is the treatment of choice in MS. Multiple Sclerosis: Description Chronic neurological disorder characterized by inflammation, demyelination and sclerosis with lesions disseminated over time and space Pathogenesis Autoimmune cause: Triggering antigen: Myelin basic protein Antibodies target: Oligodendrocytes Clinical features U/L Optic neuritis: Positive Uhthoff sign (blurring of vision on heat exposure) Sensory: Positive Lhermitte sign (Flexion at neck → Paraesthesia /shock-like sensation across the spine/back) Types Relapsing MS: Most common type , usually females, associated with Vit-D deficiency, EBV infection Primary progressive MS: Relatively late onset Secondary progressive MS: Least common Scoring scale Extended disability scoring scale (EDSS) Diagnosis Criteria: McDonald’s criteria (Option C) MRI: Dawson’s fingers (demyelination over periventricular areas); lesions dissemination over time & space seen. CSF: Oligoclonal bands + Treatment Acute: IV Methylprednisolone (Option C) Disease modifying drugs: Ocrelizumab (anti-CD20) > Natalizumab >> Mitoxantrone. Other drugs: IFN- β : least side effects and hence more preferred in chronic disease Fingolimod: SIP-1 Modulator Gatiramer acetate: Polypeptide drug Dimethyl fumarate: Krebs cycle metabolite Miscellaneous : Daclizumab, Almetuzumab, Mitoxantrone Brighton criteria (Option B): Used for Gullaine barre syndrome (GBS) and treatment of choice is IVIg (Immunoglobulin).

questions.question: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. His symptoms resolved within 20 minutes. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia and smoking. On examination, he is neurologically intact. A CT scan of the brain shows no acute infarction. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this condition?

options.A: Small intracerebral hemorrhage with rapid clot reabsorption
options.B: Embolic occlusion with reperfusion before permanent infarction
options.C: Permanent neuronal death without immediate infarction on imaging
options.D: Decreased cerebral blood flow due to chronic atherosclerosis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Embolic occlusion with reperfusion before permanent infarction. Explanation: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is a temporary blockage of blood flow, usually due to a small embolus, which resolves before permanent brain damage occurs. Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) Defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction due to the focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without acute infarction or tissue injury. A TIA typically lasts less than an hour, more often minutes. Usually resolves within 24 hours. Risk is highest in the first 48 hours following a transient ischemic attack. Etiology: Common risk factors for all TIA include diabetes, hypertension, age, smoking, obesity, alcoholism, unhealthy diet, psychosocial stress, and lack of regular physical activity. A previous history of stroke or TIA will increase substantially the subsequent risk of recurrent stroke or TIA. Pathophysiology: TIA subtypes, classified according to the pathophysiological mechanisms Large artery atherothrombosis (M/C): This may be intracranial or extracranial atherothrombosis. The mechanism may be a lack of blood flow distal to the site of arterial stenosis or an artery-to-artery embolism. Small vessel ischemic diseases: The underlying pathology is either lipohyalinosis or small vessel arteriolosclerosis. The commonest risk factor is hypertension, followed by diabetes and age. Cardiac embolism: A clot in the cardiac chamber, most commonly in the left atrium , is secondary to atrial fibrillation. Cryptogenic : This is usually a cortical pattern of ischemia without any identifiable large artery atherothrombosis or cardiac source of emboli. More recently it is often referred to as ESUS (embolic stroke of unknown source). Other uncommon causes such as arterial dissection or vasculitis. ABCD2 Score for TIA (Transient Ischemic Attack): The Risk of Stroke Parameter Criteria Points Age > 60 years 1 point Blood Pressure BP ≥ 140/90 1 point Clinical Features Speech disturbance without weakness 1 point Unilateral weakness 2 points Duration 10–59 minutes 1 point ≥ 60 minutes 2 points Diabetes Presence of diabetes 1 point Stroke Risk Based on Score: Score Stroke Risk Day 2 Day 7 Day 90 0–3 1% 1.2% 3.1% 4–5 4.1% 5.9% 9.8% 6–7 8.1% 11.7% 17.8% Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459143/

questions.question: The patient presented with stroke-like symptoms. Cerebral angiography done revealed the following finding. Which among the following is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Involves occlusion of predominantly large arteries

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Associated with vascular inflammation Explanation: Cerebral angiography shows a “Puff of smoke” appearance which is suggestive of Moyamoya disease . Moyamoya disease is a rare “Non-Inflammatory” neurological disorder characterized by occlusion predominantly involving large arteries. Moyamoya disease: Description Isolated chronic, non-inflammatory (Option B) usually bilateral vasculopathy of undetermined etiology characterized by progressive narrowing of large arteries (Option A) - distal part of internal carotid artery (ICA) , stem of middle cerebral (MCA) and anterior cerebral artery (ACA) Etiology Genetic: MYMY genes involved Drugs: Phenylpropanolamine, Cocaine, Methamphetamine Idiopathic: exact cause unknown Pathogenesis Chronic occlusion of large arteries leads to development of collaterals usually involving lenticulostriate branches - gives rise to “Puff of smoke” appearance on angiography. Vascular inflammation is absent . Clinical presentation More commonly affects Younger adults (Option C) , usually Asians . Can present with both Ischaemic - secondary to occlusion (pediatric age group) and Hemorrhagic - secondary to burst of collaterals (adult age group) stroke-like presentation . Diagnosis Cerebral angiography: “Puff of smoke”

questions.question: A 35 year old woman presents with a headache, seizures and focal neurological deficits. She has a history of oral contraceptive use. MRI venography reveals a filling defect in the cerebral venous sinus as shown in picture below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Heparin anticoagulation Explanation: The initial treatment for cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is anticoagulation with heparin followed by warfarin. Anticoagulation helps prevent further clot formation and promotes recanalization. Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) CVT is a rare condition caused by a blood clot in the cerebral veins or venous sinuses, obstructing blood flow within the brain. questions.question: As an intern in the medicine ward, you are asked to guide the nursing staff about the various supportive care measures to improve the outcome of stroke patients. Which among the following will you not advise?

options.A: Start nasogastric feeding if risk of aspiration is present.
options.B: Urinary catheterisation is recommended for routine bladder care.
options.C: Pneumatic compression stockings are indicated to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
options.D: Give antipyretics to patients with fever to prevent infarct expansion.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Urinary catheterisation is recommended for routine bladder care. Explanation: Among the given options, urinary catheterisation for routine bladder care is not recommended in stroke patients as it increases the risk of urinary tract infections in these patients, thereby increasing the duration of hospital stay . It is recommended only in cases of acute urinary retention or incontinence threatening to pressure areas . Supportive measures to improve stroke outcome 1. Airway Perform bedside screening for dysphagia and keep patients nil per oral , if swallowing is unsafe or aspiration occurs. 2.Breathing Check respiratory rate and give oxygen if saturation < 95%. 3.Circulation Check peripheral perfusion , pulse and blood pressure. Treat abnormalities with fluid replacement , antiarrhythmics and inotropic drugs as appropriate. 4. Hydration If signs of dehydration, give fluids parenterally or by nasogastric tube. 5.Nutrition Assess nutritional status and provide supplements if needed. If dysphagia persists for >48 hrs , start feeding via nasogastric tube instead of oral. Consider other routes for essential medications if dysphagia is present. 6.Glycemic control Check blood glucose and treat when levels are ≥ 200 mg/dl by insulin infusion or glucose/potassium/insulin combination. Monitor closely to avoid hypoglycemia . 7.Temperature Look for fever, investigate and treat underlying cause Control with antipyretics , as raised brain temperature may increase infarct volume. (Option D ruled out) 8. Infection control Avoid routine catheterisation to prevent UTIs. Chest physiotherapy to avoid lung infections. Avoid aspiration by nasogastric feeding if required. (Option A ruled out) 9.Pressure areas Provide pressure-relieving mattresses like water-bed, air beds. Pneumatic compression stockings and anticoagulation with heparin to reduce risk of deep vein thrombosis. (Option C ruled out) Regular frequent mobilization of patients along with physiotherapy for immobile joints like shoulders,etc. 10.Bowel and bladder care Check for constipation and urinary retention ; treat these appropriately. Avoid urinary catheterisation unless the patient is in acute urinary retention or urinary incontinence is threatening pressure areas . Appropriate dietary changes and stool softeners for constipation. 11.Psychological care Maintain a positive attitude and provide appropriate information regarding treatment options and prognosis. Antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications if indicated. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 1158,1159

questions.question: A 70 year old male presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech for the past 2 hours. His blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg, and a non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows no evidence of hemorrhage. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, for which he is on warfarin, and a recent gastrointestinal bleed 10 days ago. Which of the following is a contraindication to thrombolysis with rtPA in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Recent gastrointestinal bleed Explanation : A gastrointestinal bleed within the past 21 days is a clear contraindication to rtPA due to the high risk of rebleeding. In this case, the patient's recent GI bleed 10 days ago makes thrombolysis contraindicated. Indications and contraindications for thrombolysis Indications for rtPA in Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS) Clinical Diagnosis of Stroke: The patient presents with clinical features of acute stroke, confirmed by a neurological examination. No Evidence of Haemorrhage on Imaging : A non-contrast CT scan must exclude hemorrhagic stroke before administering rtPA. (Option D ruled out) Time Window: Administer within 3 hours of symptom onset (FDA); in some regions, the window is extended to 4.5 hours with restrictions. (Option A ruled out) Age : The patient must be 18 years or older. Contraindications for rtPA in AIS Conditions Increasing Bleeding Risk: Active internal bleeding, bleeding diathesis, recent head trauma (within 3 months), recent intracranial hemorrhage, major surgery in the last 14 days, gastrointestinal bleeding in the past 21 days, recent myocardial infarction. (Option C) Uncontrolled Hypertension: Blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. (Option B ruled out) Large Infarct Core: CT scan revealing significant edema in more than one-third of the MCA territory is contraindicated due to the risk of hemorrhage and limited benefit. Additional Points to Consider Use of Antithrombotic Agents: Concomitant use of anticoagulants requires careful evaluation to avoid increasing bleeding risk. Advanced Imaging: Techniques like CT perfusion or MRI may help identify patients eligible for rtPA beyond the standard time window, even up to 24 hours in some cases, though this approach remains investigational. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3335-3340.

questions.question: A 68 year old male presents to the emergency department 2 hours after sudden onset of left sided weakness and slurred speech. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, and a non-contrast CT scan shows no hemorrhage. His past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes and he is not on any anticoagulants. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.D: Immediate blood pressure reduction to <140/90 mmHg

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) Explanation: rtPA is the first line treatment for acute ischemic stroke if the patient presents within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and there are no contraindications , such as hemorrhage on imaging or high bleeding risk. This patient is within the time window for rtPA, and his CT shows no hemorrhage, making him a candidate for thrombolysis. Absolute Contraindications Relative Contraindications Major trauma, surgery, or head trauma within 3 weeks Prior hemorrhagic stroke Ischemic stroke within the prior 6 months Central nervous system neoplasm Gastrointestinal bleeding within one month Active bleeding Cancer Age > 75–80 Transient ischemic attack within 6 months Oral anticoagulant therapy Noncompressible punctures Traumatic resuscitation Refractory hypertension Advanced liver disease Infective endocarditis Active peptic ulcer Pregnancy or within one week postpartum. Administering rtPA can significantly improve clinical outcomes by dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the brain. Treatment for stroke- ischemic stroke Immediate Medical Support Stabilize the patient by managing airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) . Manage blood pressure : Permissive hypertension is allowed to maintain cerebral perfusion, but reduce BP if >220/120 mmHg ( reduce BP if >185/110 mmHg- for rtPA). Avoid overly aggressive reduction . (Option D ruled out) Control fever and hyperglycemia. Treat cerebral edema with mannitol or hemicraniectomy if severe. Restoring Blood Flow: Thrombolysis & Thrombectomy Intravenous Thrombolysis (rtPA): Effective within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Endovascular Thrombectomy: Best for large vessel occlusions, ideally within 6 hours ; can be extended up to 24 hours using advanced imaging. Preventing Future Strokes Antiplatelet Therapy: Aspirin for secondary prevention, delayed 24 hours post-rtPA or given immediately if rtPA not used. (Option B ruled out) Clopidogrel or ticagrelor may be combined with aspirin for short-term use. Anticoagulation: Recommended for atrial fibrillation but avoided in acute stroke unless cardioembolic source is confirmed after rtPA. (Option C ruled out) Rehabilitation Early intervention with physical, occupational, and speech therapy helps maximize recovery. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3335-3340.

questions.question: A 50 year old male patient came to the emergency room with complaints of headache, blurring of vision, altered sensorium, slurring of speech and left sided hemiparesis for 2 hours. He is a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension with irregular compliance. His vitals and CT image are given below. What is the most appropriate statement regarding management of this patient? BP - 190/110 mm Hg PR - 92/min SpO2 - 98% period.

questions.question: A 65 year old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right sided weakness, slurred speech and facial drooping for the past hour. His vital signs are stable and his blood glucose level is within normal range. The attending physician suspects a stroke. What is the most appropriate initial imaging study to confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of stroke?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Non-contrast Computed Tomography (CT) Explanation: Non-contrast CT is the gold standard initial imaging modality for stroke evaluation in the acute setting. It is fast, widely available, and highly effective at distinguishing between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke , which is critical for determining appropriate treatment. In ischemic stroke, the CT may be normal early on, but it rules out hemorrhage, which would contraindicate the use of thrombolytic therapy. Workup for stroke Initial Assessment and Stabilization Upon arrival, ensure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are stable. Blood glucose levels should be checked quickly to address hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia. Determining Stroke Type: Imaging is Key A non-contrast CT scan is the primary imaging modality for differentiating between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes. Clinical features may suggest stroke type, but imaging is essential for confirmation as no clinical finding can definitively differentiate between the two. Further Investigations: Uncovering the Cause Detailed History and Physical Exam: Consider risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, etc.) and perform a neurological exam to localize the affected brain area. Laboratory Tests : Perform CBC, electrolytes, renal function, blood glucose, lipid profile, coagulation studies, ESR, and ECG (to detect arrhythmias and signs of recent MI). Visualizing the Cerebral Vasculature: Imaging Techniques CT Angiography (CTA) : Assesses cerebral vasculature and identifies blockages/stenosis, but is performed after non-contrast CT has ruled out hemorrhage (not for stroke type differentiation). (Option C ruled out) CT Perfusion Imaging : Assesses blood flow, identifying reduced perfusion and ischemic penumbra. MRI: Provides more detail but takes longer than CT and is not as widely available, thus not the first imaging choice for acute stroke evaluation. (Option A ruled out) MRA: Offers detailed images of blood vessels, similar to CTA. Cerebral Angiography: Gold standard for vessel evaluation , used when other techniques are inconclusive or before endovascular intervention. Ultrasound Techniques : Carotid Duplex Ultrasonography assesses carotid stenosis but is not a first-line acute imaging modality; Transcranial Doppler (TCD) measures blood flow velocity in intracranial arteries. (Option D ruled out) Tailoring Investigations Based on Stroke Type Ischemic Stroke : Focuses on identifying the source of the blockage (cardioembolic, artery-to-artery embolic, small vessel disease). Hemorrhagic Stroke: Investigations focus on identifying causes of bleeding (e.g., hypertension, aneurysm, vascular malformation). Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3335-3340.

questions.question: A 70 Y/O woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset slurred speech and right-sided facial weakness that resolved after 30 minutes. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her blood pressure on arrival is 160/95 mmHg. She is otherwise stable and has no residual neurological deficits on examination. Based on the ABCD2 score, what is the total score for this patient, and how would her risk of stroke be classified?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Score 6, high risk Explanation : ABCD2 score Clinical tool used to predict the risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA). It helps stratify patients into different risk categories to determine the likelihood of having a stroke in the short term (usually within 48 hours to 7 days after a TIA). The score is based on five clinical parameters: Age ≥ 60 years = 1 point Blood Pressure Systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg = 1 point Clinical Features Unilateral weakness = 2 points Speech disturbance without weakness = 1 point Duration of Symptoms ≥ 60 minutes = 2 points 10-59 minutes = 1 point Diabetes History of diabetes = 1 point ABCD2 Score Interpretation: < 4 points Low risk of stroke (1% risk of stroke within 2 days) 4-5 points Moderate risk of stroke (4% risk of stroke within 2 days) > 5 points High risk of stroke (8% risk of stroke within 2 days) This patient’s ABCD2 score is calculated as follows: Age ≥ 60: 1 point Blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mmHg: 1 point Clinical features (unilateral weakness): 2 points Duration (10-59 minutes): 1 point Diabetes: 1 point Total score = 6 points and high risk. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK263115/

questions.question: A 55-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department after suddenly developing a severe headache, vomiting, and one-sided weakness. On examination, he is drowsy with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 10. His blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. CT of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hemorrhagic stroke?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm rupture Explanation : This patient's presentation of a hemorrhagic stroke, particularly in the basal ganglia (Putamen), is most commonly associated with long-standing hypertension, leading to the rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms in small penetrating arteries. Hemorrhagic stroke Hemorrhagic stroke is divided into intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) . ICH is bleeding into the brain parenchyma, and SAH is bleeding into the subarachnoid space. Etiology: Hypertension is the most common and major cause of hemorrhagic stroke. Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) Long standing hypertension produces degeneration of media, breakage of the elastic lamina , and fragmentation of smooth muscles of arteries. questions.question: A 62-year-old right-handed male is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. On examination, he has weakness in the right arm and face, with mild weakness in the right leg. He is also unable to speak fluently but can understand spoken language. His gaze is deviated to the left, and he has a right homonymous hemianopia. Which of the following is the most likely location of the thrombus causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: arm and face, aphasia (difficulty speaking), gaze deviation, and homonymous hemianopia - all classic features of an MCA stroke , typically affecting the dominant hemisphere. Stroke clinical features based on the location of the thrombus: Location Clinical Features Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Thrombosis Most common artery involved in stroke. Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss: More prominent in the face and upper limb than the lower limb. Dysarthria caused by both dominant and non dominant hemispheres. Broca’s aphasia (expressive) in the superior division infarct. Wernicke’s aphasia (receptive) in the inferior division infarct. Neglect Homonymous hemianopia : Loss of vision in the same visual field of both eyes. Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) Thrombosis (Option A ruled out) Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss: More pronounced in the lower limb than the upper limb. Urinary incontinence: Due to involvement of the medial frontal micturition centers. Behavioral or personality changes: Due to involvement of the prefrontal cortex (apathy, disinhibition). Abulia (lack of will) and apraxia. Upper extremity and face are spared. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) Thrombosis (Option C ruled out) Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (due to collateral blood supply from MCA). Visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects). Alexia without agraphia: Inability to read without difficulty writing (if the dominant hemisphere is involved). Contralateral sensory loss or thalamic pain syndrome: Due to infarction in the thalamus (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome). Memory impairment: If the temporal lobe is affected. Vertebrobasilar Artery Thrombosis (Option D ruled out) The clinical presentation includes ataxia, vertigo, headache, vomiting, oropharyngeal dysfunction, visual field deficits, and abnormal oculomotor findings. Patterns of clinical presentation vary depending on the location and the infarction pattern of embolism or atherosclerosis. Cerebellar Infarction Patients may present with ataxia, nausea, vomiting, headache, dysarthria, and vertigo symptoms. Lacunar Infarction Lacunar infarcts result from the occlusion of small perforating or penetrating arteries. Infarcts are smaller than 1 centimeter in diameter. Present with a pure motor or sensory loss, sensorimotor deficit or ataxic-hemiparesis. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499997/

questions.question: In patients presenting with acute ischemic stroke, MRI or CT imaging of a lesion greater than which size is most indicative of a stroke due to large artery atherosclerotic origin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) > 1.5 cm Explanation : Strokes of large artery atherosclerotic origin are typically associated with lesions larger than 1.5 cm on MRI or CT imaging. Lesions of this size suggest involvement of large vessels, while smaller lesions are more often related to lacunar infarcts. Acute Ischemic stroke Acute stroke is the acute onset of focal neurological deficits in a vascular territory affecting the brain, retina, or spinal cord due to underlying cerebrovascular diseases. Etiology: The etiology of ischemic stroke is a thrombotic or embolic event that causes an impairment of blood flow to an area of the brain. In a thrombotic event , the blood flow to the brain is obstructed within the blood vessel due to a thrombus within the vessel itself, usually secondary to atherosclerotic disease, arterial dissection, fibromuscular dysplasia. In an embolic event, debris from elsewhere in the body blocks blood flow through the affected vessel. The source of emboli can be the proximal artery, such as an atherosclerotic plaque in the internal carotid artery, causing an artery-to-artery embolic stroke distally from any proximal source, commonly from the heart. Cardioembolism Comprises patients with arterial blockages likely caused by an embolism originating in the heart. At least 1 cardiac source of an embolus must be identified to consider a possible or probable diagnosis of cardioembolic stroke. Evidence of a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke in more than 1 vascular territory or systemic embolisms supports a clinical diagnosis of cardiogenic stroke. A stroke occurring in a patient with a medium-risk cardiac source of embolism and no other apparent cause of stroke is categorized as a possible cardioembolic stroke. Large artery atherosclerosis Patients will exhibit clinical and brain imaging findings indicating either significant (> 50%) narrowing or complete blockage of a major brain artery or branch cortical artery, likely due to atherosclerosis. Presence of intermittent claudication history, TIAs in the same vascular territory, a carotid bruit, or weakened pulses. Lesions in the cortex, cerebellum, brainstem, or subcortical hemispheric infarctions > 1.5 cm in diameter observed on CT or MRI indicate potential large artery atherosclerotic origin. Duplex imaging or arteriography demonstrating more than 50% stenosis of a relevant intracranial or extracranial artery is necessary . Small vessel occlusion Patients with strokes commonly classified as lacunar infarcts in other systems. Patients should present with 1 of the typical clinical lacunar syndromes and should not exhibit signs of cerebral cortical dysfunction. Patients should have normal CT scan or MRI findings Brainstem or subcortical hemisphere lesion with a diameter of <1.5 cm. Stroke of undetermined etiology Patient with atrial fibrillation and ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%. Traditional lacunar syndrome and ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%. Stroke of other determined etiology Patients with uncommon stroke causes, such as nonatherosclerotic vasculopathies, hypercoagulable states, or hematologic disorders. Patients in this category should exhibit clinical symptoms and CT or MRI findings indicative of acute ischemic stroke, regardless of the size or location of the lesion. Diagnostic tests, such as blood tests or arteriography, should reveal 1 of these unusual stroke causes. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499997/
